data.title: Fulfilling forty: As tennis star Mahesh Bhupathi enters his fifth decade, Mail Today takes a look at his life on and off the court
data.meta_description: As the strapping champion reflected on the four decades and what he has achieved as a player, son, husband and father, Mahesh had one word to describe it: fulfiling.
data.text:
Mahesh Bhupathi turns 40 on Saturday, an important milestone for any top athlete.

Having lived out of suitcases for over two decades, he has decided The Championships at Wimbledon will be his farewell event.

As the strapping champion reflected on the four decades and what he has achieved as a player, son, husband and father, Mahesh had one word to describe it: fulfiling.

Mahesh Bhupathi, who turns forty on May 7, and longtime doubles partner Leander Paes shared great chemistry and off court they even shared a pizza. It continued till 1999, when they made it to all the four Grand Slam finals

That, perhaps, sums up the philosophy of his live-life-kingsize attitude on and off the court.

For many players, retirement is a very tough decision.

Perhaps, it is an amalgam of factors that Mahesh decided Wimbledon will be his last event where he is hoping to get into the draw with Marcin Matkowski.

Just before the French Open, Mahesh had tweeted how his heart was in Paris but the legs were not going to hold up.

That was a clear sign retirement could not be pushed back.

As one who learnt the basics of serve, forehand and backhand in Oman under the tutelage of dad CGK Bhupathi, Mahesh would himself have never imagined he would make it so big. When he started as a pro, singles was his main focus, though he was not quick on his feet.

Someone like Naresh Kumar, the former Davis Cup nonplaying captain would keep saying "his legs were bad."

The tall man worked hard on his movement and results were there to see. He won the grasscourt nationals, competed in back-to-back Challenger finals against Leander Paes on the Challenger circuit and then registered some memorable wins in Davis Cup as well.

His exploits in the World Group tie against the Netherlands in 1996 in Jaipur and the fifth rubber win over Chile's Gabriel Silberstein (1997, New Delhi) will never be forgotten.

The turning point in his career came in 1997 when he registered some incredible wins on the ATP Tour with Leander Paes as his doubles partner. From Chennai to Europe and then USA, the duo stormed the world.

The same year they also made it to the seasonending World Doubles finals in Hartford, Connecticut.

On court, Mahesh and Leander shared great chemistry and off court they even shared a pizza.

It continued till 1999, when they made it to all the four Grand Slam finals.

Perhaps, immense success was the reason for bickering with his partner. The 'Indian Express,' as the pair liked to call themselves, split, and came together again.

It became almost a habit with them but deep down there was a massive trust deficit.

If one wants to remember the good records of Leander and Mahesh, you will also have to factor their fights played out in the media.

Mahesh Bhupathi, who was born in Madras in 1974 and turned professional in 1995, won the 2012 French Open with Sania Mirza

On the personal front, Mahesh had his highs and lows.

If he was successful with eight different partners in mixed doubles, in real life he was a big hit with the women.

A broken marriage with Shvetha Jaishankar led to a second marriage with film star Lara Dutta. Today, when Mahesh talks of "fulfillment" it is in a complete sense.

It is sad he never won an Olympic medal and at the same time was always portrayed as the villain vis a vis his relationship with Leander.

Yet, tennis fans will remember him as a great team person who played with passion and pride. Unlike other athletes around the globe who wonder what to do post retirement, Mahesh has his task cut out.

Having run Globosport and managed star players like Sania Mirza, Mahesh is now the brain behind the International Tennis Premier League which will feature icons like Rafael Nadal, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi.

Mahesh Bhupathi , who will retire after playing at Wimbledon this summer, won the 2006 Australian Open with Martina Hingis

When his eyes gaze at the Wimbledon grass for one last time, you could be sure his eyes will be moist.

He used to have a bazooka serve before a shoulder injury.
